questions.text: Which of the following cells in the olfactory bulb lacks an axon?

options.label: A
options.text: Periglomerular cells

options.label: B
options.text: Mitral cells

options.label: C
options.text: Tufted cells

options.label: D
options.text: Granule cell

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the pathway of taste perception from the tongue to the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Taste signals from the taste buds are first transmitted to the gustatory cortex via CN VII, IX & X

options.label: B
options.text: The taste receptors generate nerve impulses relayed to the nucleus of the solitary tract in the medulla.

options.label: C
options.text: From the nucleus of the solitary tract, taste signals travel to the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus

options.label: D
options.text: The gustatory cortex, responsible for taste perception, is located in the medulla oblongata,

questions.correct_answer: B. The taste receptors generate nerve impulses relayed to the nucleus of the solitary tract in the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following regions is responsible for the perception of smell?

options.label: A
options.text: Piriform cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Entorhinal cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Amygdala

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior olfactory nucleus

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of sensitivity to light and occasional blurriness in his vision. During the physical examination,When light is shone into his right eye, both pupils constrict normally andWhen light is shone into his left eye, only the left pupil constricts. Given these observations, which of the following connections of the pathway is most likely affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Ciliary ganglion and sphincter pupillae

options.label: B
options.text: Edinger-Westphal nucleus and ciliary ganglion

options.label: C
options.text: Pretectal nucleus and Edinger-Westphal nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Optic tract and pretectal nucleus

questions.correct_answer: C. Pretectal nucleus and Edinger-Westphal nucleus

questions.text: Identify the labelled structures A, B, C, and D in the auditory pathway diagram.

options.label: A
options.text: A: Inferior colliculus, B: Superior olivary nucleus, C: Dorsal cochlear nucleus, D: Medial geniculate body

options.label: B
options.text: A: Inferior Colliculus, B: Lateral lemniscus, C: Superior olivary nucleus, D: Ventral cochlear nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: A: Inferior Colliculus, B: Lateral Lemniscus, C: Superior olivary nucleus, D: Trapezoid Body

options.label: D
options.text: A: Primary auditory area, B: Lateral lemniscus, C: Superior olivary nucleus, D: Spiral ganglion

questions.correct_answer: C. A: Inferior Colliculus, B: Lateral Lemniscus, C: Superior olivary nucleus, D: Trapezoid Body

questions.text: Which of the following statements about colour vision abnormalities is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Protanopia is the loss of L cones, resulting in green-blue vision only

options.label: B
options.text: Deuteranopia is the loss of M cones, resulting in red-green vision only.

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of L and M cones has X-linked inheritance, occurring in about 1% of males.

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of S cones is rare and has autosomal inheritance via chromosome 7.

questions.correct_answer: B. Deuteranopia is the loss of M cones, resulting in red-green vision only.
questions.explanation:
Color Vision Type

Cone Type affected

Perceived vision

Inheritance

Protanopia

(Red defect)

(Option A)

L Cones

Green-blue vision

X-linked

Deuteranopia

(Green defect)

(Option B)

M Cones

Red-blue vision

X-linked

Tritanopia

(Blue defect)

(Option D)

S Cones

Red-green vision

Autosomal (linked to chromosome 7)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the structure of the cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: The cochlea is a part of the outer ear and contains the ossicles.

options.label: B
options.text: The cochlea is divided into three fluid-filled compartments: the scala vestibuli, scala media, and scala tympani.

options.label: C
options.text: The organ of Corti, which contains hair cells responsible for hearing, is located in the scala vestibuli.

options.label: D
options.text: The basilar membrane separates the scala media from the scala tympani and is responsible for transmitting sound waves directly to the auditory nerve.

questions.correct_answer: B. The cochlea is divided into three fluid-filled compartments: the scala vestibuli, scala media, and scala tympani.

questions.text: Match the following types of taste with their respective mechanisms. Type of Taste Mechanism 1) Salt A) Mediated by H+ ions. 2) Sour B) Mediated by T1R2 and T1R3 GPCRs 3) Sweet C) Mediated by T1R1 and T1R3 GPCRs 4) Bitter D) Mediated by Na+-selective channels. 5) Umami E) Mediated by T2R family GPCRs.
questions.explanation:
Type of Taste

Receptor Type

Mechanism

Salt

Ionotropic Receptor (ENaC)

Mediated by Na+-selective channels

Sour

Ionotropic Receptor (H+)

Mediated by H+ ions.

Sweet

Metabotropic Receptor (GPCR)

Mediated by T1R2 and T1R3 GPCRs.

Bitter

Metabotropic Receptor (GPCR)

Mediated by T2R family GPCRs.

Umami

Metabotropic Receptor (GPCR)

Mediated by T1R1 and T1R3 GPCRs

questions.text: What is the location and the number of taste buds approximately present in the image given below

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 100, two lateral ends of the tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 5, base of the tongue

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 100, tip of the tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 25, base of the tongue

questions.correct_answer: A. Up to 100, two lateral ends of the tongue

questions.text: In the visual pathway, which of the following correctly identifies the first, second, and third-order neurons and their respective locations?

options.label: A
options.text: First-order: Bipolar cells in the retina; Second-order: Ganglion cells in the retina; Third-order: Neurons in the LGN of the thalamus.

options.label: B
options.text: First-order: Photoreceptor cells in the retina; Second-order: Bipolar cells in the retina; Third-order: Ganglion cells in the retina.

options.label: C
options.text: First-order: Bipolar cells in the retina; Second-order: Ganglion cells in the retina; Third-order: Neurons in the superior colliculus.

options.label: D
options.text: First-order: Photoreceptor cells in the retina; Second-order: Ganglion cells in the retina; Third-order: Neurons in the LGN of the thalamus.

questions.correct_answer: D. First-order: Photoreceptor cells in the retina; Second-order: Ganglion cells in the retina; Third-order: Neurons in the LGN of the thalamus.
questions.explanation:
Function

Photoreceptors

(Rods and cones)
  • Transmit signals to the outer plexiform layer.
  • They connect with bipolar and horizontal cells.

Horizontal Cells
  • Transmit signals horizontally in the outer plexiform layer.
  • Connect rods and cones to bipolar cells.

Bipolar Cells
  • Transmit signals vertically from rods, cones, and horizontal cells.
  • Connect with ganglion cells and amacrine cells in the inner plexiform layer.

Amacrine Cells
  • Transmit signals in two ways: directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner plexiform layer.
  • Connect axons of bipolar cells to dendrites of ganglion cells or other amacrine cells.

Ganglion Cell
  • Transmit output signals from the retina to the brain via the optic nerve.

Interplexiform Cells
  • Transmit inhibitory signals retrogradely from the inner to the outer plexiform layer.
  • Control the lateral spread of visual signals by horizontal cells, potentially enhancing visual contrast.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which an odorant molecule leads to the depolarisation of an olfactory cell?

options.label: A
options.text: close sodium ion channels

options.label: B
options.text: Triggers the breakdown of cyclic adenosine monophosphate

options.label: C
options.text: Initiating a signalling cascade that ultimately opens sodium ion channels.

options.label: D
options.text: The odorant molecule is transported into the olfactory cell, where it directly depolarises

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiating a signalling cascade that ultimately opens sodium ion channels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bipolar sensory neurons involved in the olfactory pathway is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Only first and second-order neurons are sufficient for olfaction to reach the level of the cerebral cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Bypasses the thalamus and directly enters the cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Each bipolar sensory neuron has 6-12 cilia

options.label: D
options.text: Olfactory bulb is the site where first-order neurons synapse with bipolar sensory neurons

questions.correct_answer: D. Olfactory bulb is the site where first-order neurons synapse with bipolar sensory neurons
questions.explanation:
Cell type

Description

Bipolar sensory neuron
  • Approximately 50 million in number.

Supporting cells
  • Secrete mucous in which the cilia of the bipolar sensory neurons are embedded.
  • Chemicals encountered by the nose (smell) are first dissolved in the mucous before being detected by the receptors.

Basal stem cells
  • Responsible for regenerating bipolar sensory neurons.

questions.text: Arrange in order the mechanism of sound transmission i) Depolarization of hair cells ii) Bending of stereocilia iii) Production of neurotransmitter glutamate iv) K & Ca enter via the channel

options.label: A
options.text: iv, iii, ii, i

options.label: B
options.text: iv, i, ii, iii

options.label: C
options.text: ii, i, iii, iv

options.label: D
options.text: ii, iv, i, iii

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the difference between outer and inner hair cells in the human cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: Outer hair cells primarily send auditory signals to the brain, while inner hair cells are involved in amplifying sound.

options.label: B
options.text: Inner hair cells are responsible for sending the majority of auditory information to the brain, whereas outer hair cells serve to amplify and fine-tune the sound vibrations.

options.label: C
options.text: Both outer and inner hair cells have the same function of sending auditory signals to the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Outer hair cells are fewer in number compared to inner hair cells and play a critical role in sound transmission.

questions.correct_answer: B. Inner hair cells are responsible for sending the majority of auditory information to the brain, whereas outer hair cells serve to amplify and fine-tune the sound vibrations.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Outer Hair Cells (OHCs)

Inner Hair Cells (IHCs)

Rows

Three rows

Arranged in a single row

Structure

Cylindrical shape; contains prestin, a motor protein

Flask-shaped; stereocilia arranged in a linear or slightly curved pattern

Function

Amplify sound vibrations; enhance sensitivity and frequency selectivity

Convert sound vibrations into electrical signals sent to the brain

Mechanism

Change length (contract and elongate) in response to sound (electromotility)

Stereocilia deflection opens ion channels, causing depolarization and neurotransmitter release

Innervation

Predominantly efferent (motor) nerve fibers

Predominantly afferent (sensory) nerve fibers

Role in Hearing

Act as mechanical amplifiers, increasing the amplitude of low-level sounds

Primary sensory receptors for hearing; transmit auditory information to the brain

Damage Impact

Loss leads to reduced hearing sensitivity and clarity, especially for soft sounds

Damage results in significant hearing loss due to impaired signal transmission

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman visits her ophthalmologist complaining of difficulty seeing in low-light conditions. She reports that her vision is fine during the day but deteriorates significantly at night. Based on your understanding of the visual pathway mechanisms in light versus dark conditions, which of the following best explains her symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased activity of rod cells in bright light.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased neurotransmitter release from photoreceptors in the dark.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased depolarisation of photoreceptors in the presence of light.

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased cGMP levels in photoreceptors during darkness.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased neurotransmitter release from photoreceptors in the dark.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between the structure of rods and cones in the human retina?

options.label: A
options.text: Rods contain the photopigment iodopsin, whereas cones contain rhodopsin.

options.label: B
options.text: Rods are primarily responsible for colour vision, whereas cones are responsible for night vision.

options.label: C
options.text: Rods have a Elongated and cylindrical outer segment, whereas cones have a shorter and tapering outer segment.

options.label: D
options.text: Rods are concentrated in the fovea, whereas cones are distributed throughout the retina.

questions.correct_answer: C. Rods have a Elongated and cylindrical outer segment, whereas cones have a shorter and tapering outer segment.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Rods

Cones

Outer Segment Shape

(Option C)

Elongated and cylindrical

Shorter and tapering

Disk Structures

(Option C)

Numerous separate disks

Fewer, continuous infoldings

Photopigment

(Option A)

Rhodopsin

Photopsins (iodopsins)

Light Sensitivity

High (sensitive to low light)

Lower (sensitive to bright light)

Color Vision

No (monochromatic)

Yes (trichromatic)

Vision Type

Scotopic (night vision)

Photopic (daylight and color vision)

Distribution

(Option D)

Throughout the retina, absent in the fovea

Concentrated in the fovea, less in the periphery

Synaptic Terminal

Spherule

Pedicle

Renewal of Disks

Continuous shedding and renewal

Continuous, slower renewal

Connection to Bipolar Cells

Many rods to one bipolar cell

One cone to one bipolar cell (in fovea)

questions.text: Which of the following best explains why rods are more sensitive to low light than cones?

options.label: A
options.text: Individual connections to ganglion cells

options.label: B
options.text: High convergence onto ganglion cells

options.label: C
options.text: Lower density in the retina

options.label: D
options.text: Larger size of photoreceptors

questions.correct_answer: B. High convergence onto ganglion cells
